articles.headline: Uber Fires Former Google Engineer at Heart of Self-Driving Dispute
articles.snippet: The ride-hailing service had acquired Anthony Levandowski’s company last year. He was accused of stealing product plans from his former employer.
articles.abstract: The ride-hailing service had acquired Anthony Levandowski’s company last year. He was accused of stealing product plans from his former employer.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber said Tuesday that it had fired Anthony Levandowski, a star engineer brought in to lead the company’s self-driving automobile efforts who was accused of stealing trade secrets when he left a job at Google.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Despite Weak Inflation, Fed Is Likely to Raise Interest Rates in June
articles.snippet: A Federal Reserve official said the board should raise its benchmark rate “soon” despite new government data showing inflation remains weak.
articles.abstract: A Federal Reserve official said the board should raise its benchmark rate “soon” despite new government data showing inflation remains weak.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A speech by a Federal Reserve governor Tuesday underscored a basic shift in Fed policy: The central bank now needs to be convinced that quarterly rate increases are a bad idea.

articles.headline: Even as Wind Power Rises, It Falls Under a Political Cloud
articles.snippet: As utility operations increasingly avail themselves of wind, the Trump administration looks at whether conventional sources have been placed at a disadvantage.
articles.abstract: As utility operations increasingly avail themselves of wind, the Trump administration looks at whether conventional sources have been placed at a disadvantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wind farms, with their rapid geographic spread and technological advances, are reshaping the electric system, defying skepticism that they are steady or reliable enough to displace conventional power plants.

articles.headline: The Billionaire Gadfly in Exile Who Stared Down Beijing
articles.snippet: Guo Wengui, an eccentric Chinese billionaire, has accused top Chinese leaders of graft. At first, the government retaliated. Then China stood down.
articles.abstract: Guo Wengui, an eccentric Chinese billionaire, has accused top Chinese leaders of graft. At first, the government retaliated. Then China stood down.
articles.lead_paragraph: The biggest political story in China this year isn’t in Beijing. It isn’t even in China. It’s centered at a $68 million apartment overlooking Central Park in Manhattan.
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Goldman Buys $2.8 Billion Worth of Venezuelan Bonds, and an Uproar Begins
articles.snippet: Goldman and other big investors have been willing to assume increasing levels of risk for high-yield investments when interest rates are near zero.
articles.abstract: Goldman and other big investors have been willing to assume increasing levels of risk for high-yield investments when interest rates are near zero.
articles.lead_paragraph: Venezuelan bonds would seem to be an unlikely target for global investors.

articles.headline: Trump Advisers Wage Tug of War Before Decision on Climate Deal
articles.snippet: The president has said he will make a decision on whether to withdraw from the landmark Paris Agreement this week, a vexing decision with voices he respects on both sides.
articles.abstract: The president has said he will make a decision on whether to withdraw from the landmark Paris Agreement this week, a vexing decision with voices he respects on both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A divided White House staff, anxious corporate executives, lawmakers and foreign leaders are fiercely competing for President Trump’s ear this week as he nears a decision on whether to pull the United States out of the Paris climate accord, the landmark agreement that commits nearly every country to combat global warming.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Diane Cardwell

articles.headline: Blind Spots in Trump’s Trade Tirade Against Germany
articles.snippet: President Trump’s campaign against the U.S. trade deficit with Germany overlooks some crucial benefits and overstates Berlin’s ability to do much about it.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s campaign against the U.S. trade deficit with Germany overlooks some crucial benefits and overstates Berlin’s ability to do much about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The last time relations between the United States and Europe were this bad — in the spring of 2003, during the buildup to the invasion of Iraq — the administration of George W. Bush decided to “punish France, ignore Germany and forgive Russia,” in a phrase attributed to the national security adviser at the time, Condoleezza Rice.

articles.headline: Deadly Bombing in Kabul Is One of the Afghan War’s Worst Strikes
articles.snippet: The blast near the Afghan presidential palace and the German Embassy, which killed over 80 and wounded hundreds, spoke volumes to the frustrations of stabilizing the country.
articles.abstract: The blast near the Afghan presidential palace and the German Embassy, which killed over 80 and wounded hundreds, spoke volumes to the frustrations of stabilizing the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A truck bomb devastated a central area of Kabul near the presidential palace and foreign embassies on Wednesday, one of the deadliest strikes in the long Afghan war and a reminder of how the capital itself has become a lethal battlefield.
articles.byline: By Mujib Mashal, Fahim Abed and Jawad Sukhanyar
